reinforcements.similarity: Both address the speed mismatch between human-mediated interactions and platform-mediated interactions. works-003 (Match Cognitive Speed to Conversational Speed) prescribes that the platform should be as fast as a phone call. works-0932-002 (Agent-to-Platform Data Bridge) provides the concrete mechanism: auto-populate the listing from call data so the host confirms rather than creates. The new element is the implementation of the existing principle for passive hosts.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: works-003 evidence: Andreas described two units in 7 seconds; the platform must match this density. works-0932-002 evidence: Anthony conveyed all listing data in 67 seconds of monosyllabic responses, but this data will not reach the platform without a data bridge. Both use the insight that phone calls already capture the data the platform needs. Combined insight: the agent call IS the first step of the platform workflow, not a separate interaction that precedes it.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the problem of hosts who will not complete multi-step platform processes. works-002 (Design for the Depleted User) prescribes smart defaults and reduced decisions. works-0932-005 (Co-Host Mode) takes this further for the most extreme case: hosts who will not engage at all. Co-Host Mode is the ultimate 'smart default' -- the entire workflow is delegated. The new element extends the depletion-aware principle to its logical endpoint: if the user is infinitely depleted (passive archetype), delegate everything.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: works-002 evidence: Kahneman's parole judge study shows depleted decision-makers default to denial (abandonment). works-0932-005 evidence: Anthony is the ultimate depleted user -- he will not complete any self-serve process. The co-host model prevents abandonment by removing the self-serve requirement entirely. Combined insight: depletion-aware design is a spectrum from 'reduce decisions' (works-002) to 'delegate all decisions' (works-0932-005), and the platform must support the full spectrum.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the handoff from human interaction to digital interaction. works-004 (Bridge Human Trust to Digital Trust) prescribes that the platform should echo the agent call's language and data. communicates-0932-002 (Pre-Populated Listing Review) specifies the exact information architecture for this bridging: a confirmation card that mirrors the call's sequential data confirmation pattern. The new element provides the concrete IA specification for the existing trust-bridging principle.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: works-004 evidence: the platform should feel like 'opening a letter from someone you just spoke with.' communicates-0932-002 evidence: the confirmation card uses label-value pairs with Correct/Edit toggles, mirroring the call's 'Bryant states data, Anthony confirms' pattern. Combined insight: the confirmation card IS the 'letter from someone you just spoke with' -- it is the concrete implementation of trust bridging through data continuity.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the System 1 assessment at phase transitions. works-001 (System 1 Trust Gate) prescribes that the first 2 seconds of every new screen must signal continuity with the prior phase. feels-0932-001 (Effortless Capture) specifies the emotional target for the onboarding transition: relief, achieved by showing pre-populated data that proves the platform was listening. The emotional design reinforces the cognitive design: relief IS the System 1 approval signal for passive hosts.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: works-001 evidence: System 1 approves transitions that show recognition before instruction (Kahneman's associative coherence). feels-0932-001 evidence: Anthony's relief emotion is triggered when the pre-populated listing appears, demonstrating that the platform heard him on the phone call. Combined insight: for passive hosts, the System 1 trust gate is passed not through visual consistency (the original element's focus) but through data continuity -- showing the host their own information proves the platform is legitimate.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the channel mismatch between host preferences and platform expectations. works-003 prescribes matching platform speed to conversational speed. works-0932-001 (Passive-Host Aggregation Pipeline) extends this to channel matching: not just speed but medium. The platform must meet passive hosts on SMS, not just make the web interface faster. This is a significant extension.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: works-003 evidence: if the host can say it in 7 seconds, they should enter it in under 15 seconds (same channel, faster speed). works-0932-001 evidence: Anthony will text photos but not upload them; his preferred channel is SMS, not the web (different channel entirely). Combined insight: speed matching (works-003) applies to hosts who will use the platform; channel matching (works-0932-001) applies to hosts who will never use the platform. Both are needed for full host spectrum coverage.

contradictions.conflict: works-002 (Design for the Depleted User) prescribes that the platform should never require the host to 're-enter information that was already provided in a prior phase.' behaves-0932-002 (Confirmation Card Toggle) introduces an auto-confirm timeout: if the host takes no action within 48 hours, all pre-filled data is auto-confirmed. This potentially conflicts with works-002's prescription that hosts should be able to 'save and resume' at exactly where they stopped. Auto-confirming after a timeout could mean the host returns to find their listing published with data they never explicitly approved.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: works-002's evidence (Kahneman's ego depletion) is a general principle applicable to all hosts. behaves-0932-002's evidence (Anthony's monosyllabic confirmation pattern) is specific to passive hosts who will never return to the platform. The auto-confirm timeout serves passive hosts at the potential cost of hosts who are simply slow to complete. Resolution: the auto-confirm should only activate for hosts explicitly flagged as passive (via engagement spectrum) or in co-host mode. For other hosts, the 48-hour timeout should save progress but NOT auto-confirm.
contradictions.recommendation: Scope the auto-confirm timeout to passive-flagged and co-hosted hosts only. For standard hosts, apply works-002's save-and-resume principle with no auto-confirmation.

contradictions.conflict: feels-0932-003 (Respectful Brevity) prescribes maximum 2 sentences per SMS and no greetings/sign-offs. communicates-0932-004 (Agent Dashboard) prescribes that agents can send batch personalized SMS using templates. There is a tension between the emotional principle (SMS must feel human and brief) and the operational reality (batch SMS from templates may feel automated and impersonal). If agents send templated messages that technically follow the 2-sentence rule but feel robotic ('LISTING: Your listing needs photos. Reply with photos.'), the brevity principle is met but the respect principle is violated.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: Both elements are from the same run, so evidence strength is equivalent. The resolution is in template design: templates must be written to sound human even at scale. The agent should be able to personalize at least one element (property address, agent name, specific detail from the call) to prevent the batch SMS from feeling like a mass mailing.
contradictions.recommendation: Add a template quality rule: every SMS template must include at least one personalized field (property address, agent name, or call-specific detail). Templates that could be sent identically to any host are rejected by the system.

extensions.gap_filled: SMS-based data aggregation pipeline for passive hosts. The existing library has no elements addressing hosts who refuse to use the web platform. All prior elements assume some level of platform engagement. This element extends the library into the 'zero-engagement host' territory.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens (Anthony + Wisdom of Crowds), but the passive host archetype is strongly evidenced by the call transcript. Medium confidence -- need at least one more passive host call (different demographic) to validate that SMS preference is a pattern, not an anomaly.

extensions.gap_filled: Independence preservation in agent-mediated decisions. The existing library addresses the agent-to-platform handoff (works-004) but not the data quality issue of agent-mediated decisions. This element extends the library into crowd intelligence territory: how to ensure platform data reflects host preferences, not just agent preferences.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens, but the theoretical foundation (Surowiecki's independence condition) is well-established. High confidence on the principle, medium confidence on the implementation (pre-recommendation signal capture needs user testing to validate that passive hosts will answer even a 1-word question before the agent recommends).

extensions.gap_filled: Crowd-calibrated pricing display. The existing library has pricing-related elements (from Kahneman depletion and anchoring runs) but none that surface aggregate market data to hosts. This element extends the library into marketplace intelligence territory.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. Medium confidence -- the principle is sound (crowds are better estimators than individuals) but the implementation risk is information cascades (hosts copying each other). Needs A/B testing to validate that showing crowd pricing data improves rather than homogenizes pricing diversity.

extensions.gap_filled: Silence interpretation framework. The existing library has no elements addressing the ambiguity of host silence. All prior elements assume the host will produce some signal (engagement, feedback, communication). This element extends the library into the 'missing data' territory -- how to extract one bit of information from a host who produces zero spontaneous signal.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. Medium confidence on the framework, low confidence on the specific check-in timing (first month, mid-lease, end-of-lease). Needs longitudinal data to determine optimal check-in cadence for passive hosts.

extensions.gap_filled: Agent-facing visual patterns. The existing library is entirely host-facing or guest-facing. This element extends the library into the agent experience: how to visually encode host engagement levels in a portfolio management dashboard. This is new territory for the design system.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. Low-to-medium confidence because the four-state engagement model (Active/Moderate/Passive/Silent) has not been validated against real agent workflows. The categories may need refinement based on agent feedback.

extensions.gap_filled: Emotional design for non-participating hosts. The existing library's emotional elements all assume some level of active participation. This element extends the library into the emotional experience of passive belonging: how to make hosts feel valued when they contribute nothing beyond inventory.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. Medium confidence -- the principle (passive hosts need value recognition, not engagement prompts) is strongly supported by Anthony's behavior. But the annual summary mechanism is untested -- passive hosts may not even open an annual summary SMS.

new_tokens_flagged: --bg-confirmation: rgb(252, 250, 255) -- proposed in looks-0932-002 as a semantic alias for --bg-off-white. This token is functionally identical to the existing --bg-off-white (also rgb(252, 250, 255)). The alias adds semantic meaning but not visual variety.

--sms-category-style -- proposed in looks-0932-004 as a combination token for uppercase, --text-xs, --font-weight-semibold, --text-purple. This is a combination token, not a primitive -- it should be implemented as a CSS class, not a CSS variable.

Token drift note: tokens.json uses warm green accent (#2d5a3d) and Instrument Serif/Outfit typography, which conflicts with the production style guide's purple palette (#31135D) and Inter/DM Sans typography. All L3 visual elements correctly use the production style guide values, NOT tokens.json values. This confirms the known drift documented in MEMORY.md.
token_compliance.recommendation: Accept --bg-confirmation as a semantic alias -- it adds clarity without adding visual tokens. Reject --sms-category-style as a CSS variable -- implement it as a .sms-category CSS class instead. Continue using production style guide values (purple palette, Inter/DM Sans) for all UI elements, not tokens.json values.

target_emotions: none from this run (passive hosts have invisible discovery)

arc_conflicts: Minor tension between 'excitement' (existing library, proposal_mgmt) and 'confidence' (feels-0932-002, proposal_mgmt). For engaged hosts, a new proposal is exciting. For passive hosts like Anthony, it should feel handled and unsurprising. Resolution: the emotional target varies by host engagement level. Engaged hosts get excitement; passive hosts get confidence. The UI can serve both by leading with the outcome (guest matched) and adding celebratory details only in the expanded view.

Minor tension between 'momentum' (existing library, onboarding) and 'relief' (feels-0932-001, onboarding). Momentum implies forward motion and energy; relief implies stillness and resolution. Resolution: for engaged hosts, onboarding should feel like momentum (they are building something). For passive hosts, onboarding should feel like relief (someone else built it). Both emotions serve the same purpose (keeping the host on the journey) through different means.
emotional_arc_check.arc_assessment: The emotional arc for passive hosts follows a coherent trajectory: relief (onboarding -- 'they already did it') -> empowerment (pricing -- 'I have useful context') -> trust (proposals/active lease -- 'someone capable is handling things') -> belonging (retention -- 'I am part of this without needing to participate'). This arc is logically sound: it moves from initial burden removal through delegated confidence to long-term passive membership. The arc does not require the host to escalate engagement at any point, which is correct for the Anthony archetype. The arc complements the existing library's engaged-host arc (curiosity -> safety -> momentum -> confidence -> calm -> excitement -> calm -> loyalty) without contradicting it.

discovery.note: Intentionally uncovered in this run -- Anthony's discovery phase is invisible (per L0 analysis). Future runs with host calls that reveal discovery behavior should target this gap.

evaluation.note: works-0932-003 (independence preservation) and feels-0932-002 (invisible competence) touch evaluation, but evaluation is not a primary focus of this run. Coverage comes from existing library elements (works-001, works-004).

onboarding.note: Onboarding is the most-covered phase in this run: works-0932-001, works-0932-002, works-0932-005, communicates-0932-001, communicates-0932-002, looks-0932-002, behaves-0932-001, behaves-0932-002, feels-0932-001. This is appropriate given Anthony's critical onboarding dropout risk.

listing_creation.note: Listing creation overlaps heavily with onboarding for passive hosts. Same elements apply to both phases.

pricing.note: works-0932-004, communicates-0932-003, looks-0932-001, feels-0932-004 cover pricing. Moderate because pricing is a single-moment interaction for passive hosts, not a sustained phase.

proposal_mgmt.note: works-0932-003, works-0932-005, communicates-0932-001, behaves-0932-003, feels-0932-005 cover proposal management. Moderate because Anthony has not yet reached this phase in his journey.

active_lease.note: works-0932-001, works-0932-005, communicates-0932-005, behaves-0932-001, behaves-0932-005, feels-0932-002, feels-0932-006. Strong coverage driven by the silence interpretation framework and ongoing co-host operations.

retention.note: works-0932-001, works-0932-003, communicates-0932-005, behaves-0932-005, feels-0932-002, feels-0932-006. Moderate -- retention elements are present but largely inherited from active_lease patterns. A dedicated retention lens would strengthen this phase.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The works layer identified the Passive-Host Aggregation Pipeline (works-0932-001) but did not specify the data schema for SMS-collected data. How does a photo texted via SMS map to the listing data model? How does a GOOD/HELP check-in response map to a satisfaction score? The works layer should specify the data transformation rules.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Technical specification of how SMS responses (text, photos, binary choices) are normalized into platform-standard data fields.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The looks layer (looks-0932-003, Host Engagement Spectrum) defined four engagement states but did not specify how the engagement level is calculated. What inputs determine whether a host is Active, Moderate, Passive, or Silent? Platform login frequency? SMS response rate? Listing completeness? The visual pattern needs a calculation model behind it.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Engagement scoring model: which signals feed the four-state classification, what thresholds distinguish each state, and how frequently the classification is recalculated.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The feels layer defined emotions for passive hosts but did not address the emotional transition if a passive host becomes engaged over time. What happens if Anthony eventually starts logging into the platform? The emotional arc should include a path from passive (relief, confidence, belonging) to engaged (curiosity, momentum, excitement) without creating a jarring tonal shift.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Emotional transition design: how does the platform's tone shift when a host's engagement level changes? Specifically, how does the SMS-first, relief-oriented experience evolve into a web-first, momentum-oriented experience?
